content.webTitle: Stephen Bates’s Diary: Not all quiet on the commercial front | Stephen Bates

fields.headline: Diary: Not all quiet on the commercial front
fields.bodyText: • A week to go before the commemorations for the centenary of the first world war go over the top, and already there is no shortage of commercial cashing in with varying degrees of tackiness. Perhaps the most extravagant is Bradford Exchange’s commemorative men’s watch: “Surrounded by a rich, gold-plated casing and complemented by a genuine leather strap, the champagne-toned dial of this unique heirloom … showcases a handsome tribute.” The limited-edition precision chronograph, with quartz movement, dials with stop-start function and battle sites expertly etched on the back, sounds just the thing for the trenches, except that at £130 it would have taken the average Tommy on a shilling a day nearly twice as long as the war lasted just to afford it. We’ll leave it to the all-action mechanism to calculate equivalent monetary values. • Slightly less exasperating, though still pretty patronising, the CofE’s Dover diocese is suggesting that parishes should invite the elderly to tea and serve them shortbread with poppy seeds and poppy-seed brioches with raspberry jam. The seeds of course stand in for the poppies that blew between the crosses row on row in John McCrae’s famous poem. If you are also short of commemorative poppy seeds for the garden, your local B&Q is selling seeds from Flanders “as a visible and colourful reminder” of the sacrifices the men then made. Half the proceeds go to the Royal British Legion, which is also supported in its admirable work by those well-known peacemakers at BAE Systems. • Things that could have been better expressed: a Metropolitan police survey of residents in Brent asking what they think of the service, entitled “Listening to one million Londoners”. I suppose that only leaves 12 million they’re not listening to. • An ominous straw in the wind for David Cameron in the shape of a weekend tweet by Rupert Murdoch: “Asked is my daughter friend of David Cameron. Don’t know but hope not.” The old boy’s holidaying in Maine and clearly has time on his hands to make mischief. Of course he has absolutely no influence over his newspapers’ editorial allegiances. None whatsoever. • Those pictures of Prince George, our third in line to the throne, toddling about on his first birthday last week went down well on the other side of the Channel – his clothes were from the French children’s clothing firm Petit Bateau. They were understandably thrilled, especially when the pictures went viral and the clothes immediately sold out. “We couldn’t imagine a better ambassador than this lively little boy,” oozed the firm’s managing director, momentarily misplacing his Gallic republicanism. Hmmm: shouldn’t our royals be flying the flag for British manufacturers on such an occasion? Are there no romper suits in John Lewis? The French take these things seriously: when President Hollande showed off his new spectacles recently he was immediately taken to task for choosing Danish frames instead of local ones. He tried really hard to make amends by ordering some proper French sunglasses – only to be told he couldn’t have them before September. Hélas, the workers need August off too. • Still, it must be some comfort to the hard-pressed French taxpayer that the departure of Valérie Trierweiler, the president’s squeeze, and her entourage from the Élysée Palace has saved €500,000 a year, according to the annual governmental audit uncovered by Le Canard Enchaîné. It’s an ill wind. • Rather a shame the enterprising idea by local Brownies in Leamington Spa to lend homeless folk tents to sleep in has been met with quite such a douche of cold water by the local council. They don’t want riff-raff sleeping in their nice clean parks this summer and have started confiscating the tents. Health and safety considerations and planning contraventions, of course, a spokesperson for Warwick district council helpfully explained to the Leamington Observer: “We’d much prefer any organisation distributing tents refer the person to us so we can make proper, lasting arrangements which might include signposting them to other support networks or assisting them into better temporary accommodation.” Pity the council didn’t save the guides the trouble earlier.
